Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Modeling Protein Degradation - Evaluation of Strategies and Targets

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: The ability to manipulate the concentration of individual proteins in a cell is limited, for example, by the lack of knowledge of the factors that regulate protein stability. In this project the response of yeast cells to oxidative stress will be used to develop predictive models of protein degradation based on protein sequence and structure. The approach will employ mass spectrometry and bioinformatics to combine proteomic data (including protein ubiquitination status and degradation) with information on protein sequence and structure to learn features that impact protein stability. Predictions will be validated in targeted experiments. Broader Impacts: Interdisciplinary training will be provided to graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, and engagement with high-school students will be achieved through participation in the American Museum of Natural History's LANG program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project proposed to use a combination of experimental and computational methods to predict protein stabilities, both under normal conditions and under stress. The regulation of stability, along with synthesis, one of the major factors affecting the protein composition of our cells. The experimental methods used in this project involved large-scale approaches that monitored stabilities for several hundreds to thousands of yeast proteins. We used computational processing to normalize the data and rate models to infer protein half-lives. In the course of the project, we revealed that proteins in yeas are very stable and their half-life comprises many hours. Most yeast proteins are under normal conditions primarily diluted due to continuous cell division rather than actively degraded. These results consolidate an ongoing debate on protein stability which reported protein half-lives between minutes and several hours. 

The experiments also monitored modifications of the proteins that lead to protein degradation. While pursuing these experiments, the project discovered an entirely new pathway for the cell to respond to stress, using one of the protein modifications that the methods monitored. This modification is called ‘ubiquitin’ and is attached in different chain formations to the target protein. Our experiments showed that new pathway does not affect the degradation machinery, but the protein synthesis machinery, i.e. the ribosome. We further developed methods to understand the mechanism by which ubiquitin affects ribosome function and again found a new pathway. Ongoing work confirms the protein factors whose binding is modified by ubiquitin and that therefore halt translation under stress. 

Therefore, the overall outcomes of this project provide exciting new data for a regulatory interplay between protein modification, degradation, and synthesis. 

We relayed this work and its results to the general public via several outreach programs that we participate in. We annually participate via lectures in the Johns Hopkins Center for Talented Youths trip to New York City, in the World Science Festival, and by 10 week laboratory internships via the NYU K12 STEM ARISE and the NYU Courant GSTEM programs. All programs aim at diversifying participating groups.

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2017
Modified by: Christine Vogel
